,

I appreciate your participation and opinions on this topic.

Questions, =
discussions, and constructive criticism will help all of us
 learn more abo=
ut the problems and challenges of testing and how to

So let =
me start :-).  I will start not by talking about Agitator, but
about a more=
 general issue: is there a problem with unit testing that
needs solving?

Y=
ou write:

> The bottom line is that this is a very interesting product tha=
t  
> appears to me to be looking for a problem to solve. 

I believe that =
there's a HUGE and GROWING problem to solve.  My
co-founder (Dr. Roongko Do=
ong, another person who is as passionate
about advancing the state-of-the-a=
rt in test automation for 15+
years), started Agitar not because we were lo=
oking for something to
do, or make a quick buck (quite the contrary, in 200=
2 when we started
Agitar I was Senior Director of Software Engineering at G=
oogle - if
all I cared about was money I would have stayed put :-)).  We st=
arted
Agitar to solve what I believe is one of the biggest problems in
soft=
ware development, and one that we are very passionate about:
getting develo=
pers to think about and do testing DURING development -
so they can address=
 defects and design problems with maximum
efficiency and minimum impact.  A=
s opposed to the more traditional 
"throw the code over the wall to QA" mod=
el.

My experience at Google, where with others I championed the
introducti=
on of JUnit and the idea of developer testing was very
revealing.  Admitted=
ly, Google is a way off the chart in terms of
programming talent, but in th=
e last 4 years I confirmed the very same
findings with 100s of other people=
 and software organizations that
also introduced, or tried to introduce, de=
veloper/unit testing:

Here are some of the key things I discovered:

1) On=
 average, approximately only 30% of developers who are introduced
to xUnit/=
developer-testing/TDD become test-infected (i.e. the will
continue to do un=
it testing even if they are not asked to).  The other
70% will go back to t=
heir "old-ways".  Why is that?  My next points
sheds some light.

2) Most d=
eveloper complained that in order to get decent coverage (say
80-90%) they =
have to write 3-4 lines of JUnit code for every line of
Java.  They wanted =
some way to automate the most mundane parts of the
testing effort and retai=
n control of the areas that require human
intelligence, insight, domain-kno=
wledge, and creativity.

3) Most of the unit tests that actually get writte=
n cover only the
normal/"happy" path.  They assume the best of all possible=
 world; that
they would never be passed bad parameters, that all strings wo=
uld be
nice ASCII code and never exceed some magic length, that all objects=

will be well formed and in the state they were expecting, etc. 
Needless t=
o say, this is not sufficient for most industrial
applications, especially =
if they have to survive in hostile
environments where hackers look for ever=
y possible deficiency in the
system, or when your colleagues assume that yo=
u are going to handle
those null pointers so he does not have to worry abou=
t them. On the
other hand, if you want to cover all those contingencies tes=
ting
becomes a combinatorial problem and it's hard for developers to
concei=
ve of and test for everything that should be tested for.

4) If testing a p=
articular piece of code was too complicated (lots of
dependencies, complica=
ted set-up, lots of things to mock, etc.) the
tests were skipped.  This is =
human nature. Ideally people would look
at code that's difficult to test an=
d think re-factoring and (re)design
for testability but most people are not=
 there yet.

5) Test maintenance was as time consuming as code maintenance.=
  If
there's anything that most developers disliked more than writing lots
=
of test code by hand, was maintaining that code.  One of the most
common un=
it test maintenance patterns is: delete or comment-out
failing tests.

So, =
for someone who believes that developer/unit testing is the right
thing to =
do - one of the MOST important things to do and do WELL - I
saw a VERY big =
and VERY definite problem.  Namely: Most developers
want and need help with=
 their testing effort.  Without some help and
automation they will either g=
ive up on developer/unit testing or, even
worse because it gives a false se=
nse of security, write some trivial
"happy-path" tests that pass too easily=
 and fail to cover some
critical conditions.  Note that I am not in favor o=
f complete
automation (press a button get some passing tests) unless you ne=
ed
some quick change detector. I want Agitator to do for software
developer=
s what spreadsheets have done for accountants and business
people: raise th=
e level of abstraction, allow the user to focus on the
important things tha=
t require their intelligence and understanding
(e.g. formulae in spreadshee=
ts, test data/assertions in Agitator),
provide a number of other related ut=
ilities (e.g. graphs in
spreadsheets, code coverage and code rules and dash=
board reports in
Agitator).

We could argue whether Agitator helps with som=
e of the problems (I
believe it does since it was designed to address them =
specifically),
but I don't think we can argue that there is no problem to b=
e solved
when it comes to developer testing.  Until most developers and
sof=
tware development organizations practice thorough unit testing on a
consist=
ent basis, we have a problem.

Without JUnit we would not be where we are t=
oday.  A 30% test
infection rate is a huge step from what it was before (i.=
e. ~0%).  But
I refuse believe that we cannot augment and provide developer=
s with
other tools beyond JUnit, and that we are stuck at 30% test infected=
.

There's work we all have left to do.

People like you are helping our co=
mmon cause doing what you do best
and, presumably, like to do best: trainin=
g, coaching, mentoring,
educating, writing, etc.

Me?  I am a software tool=
 maker.  That's what I do best, and that's

st way I can help the cause.  I

, and that the right tools

s me, or has talked

 I

ique experience, skills, and vision to the table.
